p: Author centrality includes measures of how well connected an author is within the network. The number of co-authors an individual has during the period under analysis is recorded as degree centrality; a count of the number of direct links from a given node (Freeman 1979). Betweenness centrality is a measure of how frequently a given node appears along the shortest paths between all other pairs of nodes in the network. A high betweenness centrality indicates an author with the potential to broker and control the flow of information between other nodes in the network (Freeman 1979).
